div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: ORIENTAL NATIONALISM.
div.p: The great success of an Asiatic people in Japan is being turned to good account by Indians in their current magazines. In the "Modern Review" there is a well-drawn con trast between education in Japan and India
The mere figures contrasted are by no means inoculated to stimulate our national self-complaincy;--

The popalation of Japan is 46 or 47 millions It approaches most closely to Madras in area and the United Provinces in population, whilst British India asa whole bas a population five times as large. But while Japan spends at least five millions sterling out of her public funds on education, the cost to the public revenues in British India is less than a million and » half, To make the expenditure equal to that of Japan, it should have been at least 27 millions, or eighteen times as much as it now is. In fact, the State and the local an- thorities in British India spend. less on educa- tion in all its aspedts than what the tiny king- dom of the Mikado spends on educational

buildings alone, aod the latter amounts to only 26 per cent. of the total dost of education in Japan. The State expenditure on education is Rs. 1-12-4 pies per head in Japan, in British Indian it is a little over an anna! Even the small State of Baroda spends seven annas per head on education. That Japan is not excep tionally liberal in this respect will appear from the tact that Germany spends Ra. 5-7-2 pies . France, Rs. 3-18-11 pies; Re 3 Spain, Rs. 1-74 pies; and Italy Rs.1-1-11 pies, per head on education. The smaller States of Europe spend even more.

To us if seems that different results in Japan and in India can only be accounted for by the difference in the policy of the respective Governments which control education in the two countries. The sim of the one is to tum out perfect and complete man, strong and self-reliant, that ot the other is to create subor dinates in Government and mercantile offices, so as to render the work of forgein administra tion and exploitation possible

Mr. Alfred Stead in the "Hindustan Review," expounds to our Indian fellow-subject the glories of Japanese patriotism. He says that the continuous devotion of the Japanese to their deceased ancestors and to their Em- peror as the embodiment of all that is venerated in the nation's past has been going on for over 2,500 years. If thoughts have power, what power, he asks, must not these thousands of years have generated ! The veneration reaches the present day with accumulative force im possible of comprehension, and create in the Japanese people a patriotic and loyal force of inconceivable magnitude. He finds that in religious matters the Western world may learn from Japan the dangers of a State Church, the elimination of politics from religion, tolerange and a desire to seek out and help on the best in all creeds, and an insistence on practical and philosophical religion
Mr. V. G. Pradhan describes the Japan Women's University, begun in 1900.

In the "Modern Review" the India of to-day is contrasted with France in the period preced- ing the Revolution. The writer urges that the same causes which were responsible for famine in France before the Revolution exist in India to-day. Indian self-government has been an nihilated or reduced to ithpotende, even as was the case in France. An article on how the epoy is housed contrasts the official optimism f the supreme Indian anthorities with the very unsatisfactory reports tendered by the district principal medical officers. There cer tainly is a strong case made out for barrack reform.

Mr. S. C. Mookerjee insists that with the India of to-day prostrate under the heel of the foreigner, her national gospel must be that of sorrow, also that of repentance for national failings in respect of polytheism, easte degrada tion of woman, lisentiousness and an ignorant priesthood, He insists that it is necessary for the English people to be at the helm in India They are a superior race, and Indians must aspire to be their equal in manly virtues

In the "American Review of Reviews," Mr. W. M. Zumbro, President of the Ameri can College in Madura, writes that India is a nation in the making. The trouble prevailing there at present is simply the of birth There are three dominant notes ip marmor of discontent—one political, nother industrial, the third religiovs and social. The industrial discontent is due to the fact that scientific and industrial education has been almost wholly neglected, and the educated classes kept sloof from industrial parsuits. 'The result on agri- cultare is painful to contemplate. The net vrea of the land that is cropped is only about 37-5 per cent. of the total area, while more than 18 per cent. of the total area that can be cul tivated is left waste. The old industries are declining, and "caste exclusiveness, suspicion and lack of business integrity make it as yet impossible, save among the Parsees, for the people to organise commercial enterprises." He recognises that England means to do the fair thing with India, sometimes slowly and gra dually, but in the long ren determined thet India shall have a square deal, and in time a government of her own

div.head: A False Rumour
div.p: We are informed that the rumour to the effect that the State Railways Administration propose raising the passenger rates on their system in the near future is entirely withont foundation, the matter, for the present at least, having received no consideration

div.head: Italian Schools.
div.p: Mr. Comandini, a Member of the Italian Parliament, and President of the Union of Italian Professors, is coming to Egypt in order to inspect the Italian schools here. On his return to Italy he will present a report to the Italian Chamber on the state of the schools in Egypt and the Levant.

div.head: A Terrible Hail Storm.
div.p: Yesterday afternoon a very severe thunder storm passed over Port Said, accompanied by heavy rain and hail. The hail-etorm was very severe for some 10 minutes, and many windows were broken and trees damaged. Hail stones weighing 180 grams were picked up, while others weighing 80 and 90 grams fell in hundreds. Never before has the like been seen in Port Said

div.head: The Mixed Tribunals.
div.p: Judge Tuck presided on Satarday for the first time after the long vacation. We are in formed that there ate about 600 commercial cases awaiting trial. M. Biagiotti the Chiet Registrar of the Mixed Tribunals returned from leave and.has resumed his duties. We understand that there are also about 600 civil cases for trial, making in all abont 1200 cases to be disposed of.

div.head: A Benha Tragedy.
div.p: About six weeks ago a well-known and wealthy native of Benha, Hag Khadr by name, was murdered. No traces of the murderer or of his victim's corpse were discovered until three days ago when the body was found by Mansour Bey Nosseir, a notable of the Sharkieh province, and a friend ot the deceased who was vnremitting in the search for the body. Two arrests have n made at Zagazig and an enquiry is being held by the Mondir of Sharkieh

div.head: Alexandria's New Pier
div.p: The concession granted on the 5th inst. to Mr. W.O. Joseph of the Opera Square, Cairo for a 50 years concession for the sole right to construct and work a Promenade Pier within the area between Silsiley and Kait Bey, on the East Port Alexandria, stipulates that before the expiration of nine months trom the above mentioned date, Mr. Joseph must form a Com pany with a minimum capital of £125,000 to take over and work his concession. The Company has to build a pier carrying acasino, cafe, res taurant, baths, and landing stages for pleasure boats. At least LE. 80,000 have to he spent on the constraction. Tbe whole work is to be completed within three years of the flotation of the company, and to the satisfactior. of the Municipality. The Municipality will receive 10% of the yearly profits of the Pier Company, and, if they wish to do so, they can take over the concern on certain conditions at any time after 25 years. At the expiration of the con cession, the whole property will revert to the town without any compensation being payable.

div.head: DEATH OF GERMAN CONSUL.
div.p: Suez, Tuesday

I regret to announce the death of Mr. Th Meyer, German Consul, and Agent for the Norddeutscher Lloyd, and Russian Volunteer leet, who died yesterday afternoon at 5.45 pm. at Suez after a long illness. Mr Meyer was one of the oldest residents of Suez and vuch respected both by Europeans and natives His funeral, which took place at 4 o'clock this iftemoon, was attended by the Governor, all the Consuls, Shipping Agents, and residents of Snez All the consulates, shipping agencies, and several other houses flew their flags half-mast

div.head: BRITISH CONSULAR COURT
div.p: A judge of the Supreme British Consular Court will visit Alexandria next month to hear such cases as may be brought' before him. The only case of importance at present registered is that of theft of jewellery hy an Englishman named Clayton

The S.S. "Persian Prince" left London on the 22nd inst., and is due to arrive at Alex andria on or aboot the 8th November.

div.head: WALL STREET'S NEEDS.
CONFERENCE FOR RELIEF.
div.p: POSSIBILITIES OF A PANIC
(Garette's Special Service.)
London, Wednesday.

The New York bankers and financiers are conferring to devise steps to check a panic. The "Daily Telegraph" says that two ways are open. One is to form a fifty million dollars pool to support the market and to import gold to the extent of three to five millions sterling. The second is to issue clearing house certi- ficates. The latter seems to meet with favour. It is anticipated that another trust company will be in difficulties. The best informed bankers say that Wall Street needs fifty mil lion dollars to face the situation.

div.head: CORPORATION OF WESTERN EGYPT
div.p: FANTASIA AT QARA

A fantasia arranged by Messrs. Gusman and Dentamaro took place at Qara on Sunday to celebrate the completion of their contract for the construction of the formation of the West- ern Oases Railway. The party from Cairo con- sisted of Johnson Pasha and Mr. A. P. Mack, directors of the Corporation of Western Egypt, Mr. B. Dentamaro, Mr. W. C. Seales, local secretary of the Corporation, various members of the staff of Messrs Gusman and Dentamaro anda large number of friends interested in, or connected with, the work. Special cars had been reserved on the 8 o'clock train from Cairo on Saturday evening, and an excellent dinner was served by the Wagon Lits Company. On their arrival at Khargeh junction at 7 o'clock on Sunday morning one of the trains of the Western Oases Railway, gaily decorated with bunting, was waiting to convey the party to Qara, where the fete was to be held. The féte ground was gay with multi-coloured streamers and Chinese lanterns and a crowd of upwards of 5,000 natives were already thronging the Most of these men had actually been engaged the formation work. All the surronnding villages were represented by their omdehs and sheikhs, some having travelled all the way Yrom distant Khargeh The sports programme, which comprised events for both Europeans and natives, was carried out without a hitch, the camel race (natives) being keenly contested. Several of the Awassim Bedouins gave a very interesting display of horsemanship, and a troupe of dancing girls performed at intervals

The menus provided for lunch and dinner were excellent. At the dinner Johnson Pasha, speaking in French, proposed the toast of Messrs. Gusman and Dentamaro and expressed the satisfaction which the directors felt at the manner in which the work had been carried out, Mr. Dentamaro replying on behalf of his firm. Mr. Gusman is at present in Europe but his secretary, Mr. Pleimes, responded on his be- half, and proposed 'Success to the Corpora- tion" coupling the name of Mr W.C. Horn- blower with the toast, which was received with acclamation. After dinner there was @ pyro- technic disp'ay, one large set piece flanked on either side by the English and Italian flags and reading, "Viva C. W. EB. Limited and F. G. and E. D." being very fine

On Monday the guests were taken for a trip into the desert on the new railway, returning to Cairo by the night train in the special car- riages which had been awaiting them on the aiding at Kharga junction since their arrival on Sunday morning

Messrs. Gusman and Dentamaro are to be congratulated upon the way in which they have avcomplished the difficult work with which they were entrusted, the greater part of which was done under the personal superintend. ence of Mr. Dentamaro. The road, though only a narrow guage one, offered more difficulties in construction that any other in Egypt, the ground over whieh it had to be laid rendering it impossible to obtain material for the forma tion near at hand in a large number of places, and it required all the through organization, which was fortunately in evidence, to keep labourers at work during the hot months of the summer when the hardest part of the work was in hand.

The fantasia was a fitting termination to a successfal work, and all the parties concerned are to be congratulated on the admirable way in which the arrangements were carried out from start to finish, The catering and sleeping arrangements on the Wagon Lits were in all respects perfect

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN LIBERALS.
div.p: Mohamed Bey Wahid, leader of the Egyp- tian Liberal Party, is being bitterly attacked by the Nationalist Press because he sent £10 to the Lord Mayor of London for the poor asa thank offering for the restoration of Lord Cromer's health.

div.head: MISR L'IL-MISRYEEN.
KAMEL'S GREAT ORATION
div.p: A PACKED HOUSE.

Truly the house which greeted Mustapha Pasha Kamel yesterday evening was packed to overflowing by an enthusiastic crowd of sheikhs and students, and a fairly large assembly of the man in the street, while not a few Syrians, Jews, and representatives of Buropean nations were present to hear the great discourse of the illustrions Pasha. His entrance on the stage was the signal for an outburst of applanse and as the leader of the Nationalist party stood before the table, on which was placed at either end a candle to illuminate his beaming countenance, the hall reechoed with the cheers of a multitade of ardent nationali When the cheering had subsided the speaker thanked his audience for their hearty greeting, and in response came a shout of "Ya ashab al watan," while others cried "long ive Mustapha Pasha Kamel." Throughout his speech the Pasha was so londly applauded that he had to appeal to his audience to restrain their exuberance, but he must have been somewhat diseoncerted by the fact that the applause came at inopportune momenta, Indeed, the audience became so lax that it was necessary for the Pasha to exclaim at more than one part of his speech "Now you may cheer and clap." The speech lasted an hour and a half, and we cannot but record that as the time passed away the audience appeared to tire and the applause became less and less frequent. Despite his eloquence Kamel was unable to hold his andievee, though this is hardly suprising in view of its composition, for, as far we could judge, no' politician or Egyptian of note was present to sapport the would-be leader of a national movement. His ardour, none the less, was unabated and he spoke with fervour emphasised by excited gesture. Though speaking with eloquence, we must accuse our vonfrere of vain repetition. The keynote of his speech was "Were I not an Egyptian, I would haveliked to be an Egyptian for the Egyptian's sake." Would it be unfair at such a moment to cast a doubt upon the true Egyptian descent of the pseudo-patriot?

In the course of his speech he dealt with the Lambert and Denishwai affaira, Lord Cromer and his policy, Mr. Dunlop's misdeeds, ete. He alluded indirectly to the Syrian colony in Egypt by warning his hearers against the tricks of that section of the inhabitants of Egypt, who had come here hungry and withoat resources and in spite of the kindness with which they had been received they acted in a treacherous manner. Kamelearnestly impressed on his audience the necessity for rallying around him as their leadér. He of course did not neglect to deal with religion and dwelt with great reiteration on the vital necestity for religious education in the schools. He concluded that there was no need to despair as there was no doubt of the ultimate inde pendence of Egypt

div.head: THE OCCUPATION OF EGYPT
div.p: MR BLUNTS "VERITE VRAIE".
"WITHDRAWAL" OF MALET.

Our readers will have observed from our special service telegrams of the 12th, 16th, and 19th. inst., that Sir Rdward Malet has exposed Mr. Blant to the world as an historian of very imperfect acourracy, and one who would rather mislead a reader than present to him an anbiassed chronicle of facta, should it be possible thereby to cast discredit on the nation of which he is an unworthy subject. What- ever interpretation he may now choose to pot upon his references to Sir Edward Malet in his latest book, "Secret History of the English Occupation of Egypt", it cannot be denied that the conclusion most likely drawn from those references are that Sir Edward Malet was withdrawn from Cairo at the insti- gation of Mr. Blont. This is most clearly shown by the thee (1882) British Agent and Consul- General in his letter to the "Times", the full text th we now have before us. As a selfavowed traitor to his country and an intimate friend and influential counsellor of Arabi Pasha, it was not surprising that Mr. Blunt should do his utmost to mar the career and irretrievably damage in the eyes of the public one who strove to maintain the interests of his Empire land respond to the calls of a nation which was threatened with disaster. Mr. Blant, as nucleus of the Arabi rebellion, could hardly have been expected to write in generous terms of so honest and open-minded a man as Sir Edwrad Malet, and his charges of ignorance, incapacity, and treachery came las no surprise to those who had followed the trend of events ; bat, as Sir Edward Malet points oat, Mr. Blont has contributed in no small degree to "misguided history" by stating that at the most critical moment of the rebellion Sir Edward Malét was ordered on board ship by her Majesty's Government at his instigation. On the 15th of June, Mr. Blunt, who was engaged in London at the time in his intrigue in support of Arabi, received from Sabunji, his agent in Egypt, a telegram which lcontatned the following :—"Recall Malet, for God's sake. All carse and will nvurder him if he continues," and in his diary Mr. Blunt re- marks "I went at once to Eddy Hamilton [Mr. Gladstone's private secretary] and implored him to get Malet removed on board ship." He theo speaks of Sir Edward Malet "having been withdrawn" and later mentions the "re moval of Malet," and to put aside all doubt as to what Mr. Blunt intended the public to infer we torn to the index, where, under the heading "Malet", we find "Author gets him ordered lon board ship (p. 886)." Bat no such order was ever given. Fearing that his life was in grave danger Lord Granville did telegraph to Edward -Malet advising him to go on board ip (he was at this time in Alexandria) and to conduct his business from the harbour, but the British Agent realised what panic might result from such aetion on his part and so lhe stuck to his guns. He received from Lord Dufferin, who 'was at Constantinople, the following telegram: "You seem to be the only man in Egypt who has not lost bis head. I have watched all you have done with the greatest admiration." On June 17th, Sir Ed- ward Malet was struck down by a mysterious fever (the resalt of poisoning) of which he nearly died, but at midnight on the 18th the fever passed away as mysteriously as it came, thongh leaving the patient prostrate. (On the 23rd he was carried on board the "Mongolia" land on his arrival at London on the 10th of July he was told by Lord Granville that the Government were only anxious that he should get well as speedily as possible in order that he might return to Egypt and resume his duties.

Such is the trne history of the "withdrawal" of Sir Edward Malet at the instigation of Mr Blunt. But can we be surprised at such distor tion of facts by the pen of one to whom the spirit of Little-Englandism is the breath of life? Proud of his considerable share in the rebellion of 1882, proud of the terrible carnage and loss of property of which he was the main cause, for without his incitement it is very doubtful whether Arabi would have had the courage to lead a rebellion, Mr. Blont makes use of his too ready pen to contribute di storted facts to 'misguided history" aud to cast undeserved ignominy upon his contem- poranean politicians, Such men we cannot but consider as self-interested. Unable to gain fame, M. Blunt mast needs seek notoriety, and with such an end in view he uses Arabi Pasha asa tool with which to grind his own axe. He has, indeed, secured bis goal. Foremost among Little Englanders, he has gained that notoriety which any man, deserving of the name, would seorn. He can delight in the applause of his country's enemies, and it is to hima pleasure to be despised by his compatriots. We cannot believe that such men as Mr. Blunt truly desire the betterment of their fellow-beings or the uplifting of enfeebled races. Anti-patriots well know that the power of speech or pen earns for them a despicable notoriety, flashes their names be useful to alien countries in the future, and in such they glory. It is their proad boast that they have made every effortto poison the nation which has nursed them, and with such an object in view they welcome with avidity evidence which they know to be of merely apparent veracity, witch can be readily confounded by scratching the mengre veneer which makes it presentable to the world. In all his writings Mr. Blont has shown himself eager to accept the most baseless testimony available, and this is eapedially evident in his version of the deplorable Denishwai incident. Therein he twists and turns facts to represent the view he, in the full spirit of Little-England- ism wishes to offer to the public, and so it is with his "Secret History of the English Occu- pation of Egypt." Ever eager to prove his country in the wrong, always ready to discredit a faithful servant of the State, he has recorded the events of 1882 with a marvellous disregard of accuracy and recorded as facts what the light of day proves to be inventions. We cannot but welcome Sir Edward Malet's empathetic denial of Mr. Blunt's statements, for by such utter descredit is cast upon a volume which should never have been written, and which is a lasting disgrace to the hand that penned it.

div.head: DEPORTATION OF CRIMINALS.
div.p: Woulf it be advisable to introduce a law whereby the Egyptian Government would be vested with the power of deporting criminals? This proposal, which is carried would be likely to be infinitely far reaching in its results, in being mooted at the present time, and on the whole it appears that public opinion is inclined to support it, though no definite scheme has yet been arrived at.

In our opinion such a law, as applying to specail cases and under special circumstances, would have a distinctly beneficial effect, the dread of banishment being certainly calcuated to produce a most salutary impression on the minds of evil doers

It is, however, a step which will require the most careful consideration, the drastic nature of the proposal making it inevitable that it would, in the majority of cases followed by results as active as the measure taken to pro- sure them, and it is a full appreciation of this fact which we must endeaveur to absorb before making such a law absolute.

It would necessitate the formation of a special court to investiagte such cases as would seem to warrant the application of the new code, and this court, once formed, whould be granted the most absolute power and freedom possible in dealing with such cases as it would be called upon decide

It would be impossible, or to say the least inevitable, to form any schedule of crimes which would, or would not, come within the jurisdiction of the new law. Each case would have to be tried on its individual cha- racteristics, the previous record, associations, temperament, and even hereitary, of the accused looked upon as factors in the case, and the law, if made at all should be made applic able to all crime irrespective of its nature.

The habitual thier, who has perhaps never stolen goods to the value of more than a few piastes at a time, and who is yet never out of prison but what he is at his old work again, the confirmed drunkard, and the mob of worthless idlers who hang about the street courses of our large towns, these men should be equally liable to deportationas well as those who have commit ted greater crimes; indeed it is with the former class that such a law would be principally called upon to deal

A contemporary has affirmed that no di munition of crime would result in the event of the law being brought into effect. It argues that a criminal when committing a crime does so in the hope that his action will remain un discovered, and that therefore the thought of deportation would hold no terrors for him

It is a pity that this wonderful discovery was not made before; it would have saved the nations much time and money; but even now we venture to diagree, and to suggest that were man taken from his particular walk of crime and deported beyond the seas, his com rades would be almost tempted to forego the gains of petty thefts on which they had form erly thriven, and might even seek to ward off the pange of hunger by a little wholesome work in preference to taking a compulsory trip to a strange land of which they know nothing

It is the ease in which this class lives that brings it its ever increasing number of recruits. Prison is looked upon after a time as just one of the interludes of life, unpleasant perhaps, but not half as unpleasant as regular work would probably be, but remove the man from the associations of his former life, place him in a spot where it is necessary to his own well being that he should work, instil into his mind the fact that a relapse into his former habits would but mean an extension of the time he will be forced to spend in an alien land, and the change wrought would be likely to prove of a lasting character, even after his return to his own country

We say that the law, put before the country on a proper basis, and with full powers is a thoroughly sound one and worthy of immediate consideration. Excercise the maximum amount of care in the choosing of the officals in whose hands the administration of the law would lie, and we image that it would, even beofre its first case had been tried, prove of benefit to the country

div.head: KAMEL AND THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: Considerable attention has been drawn to the institution whuch Mustapha Pasha Ka mel has made in "Al Lewa" against the Khedive "Al Moayad" in reply to this criticism publishes an article with the title "What does the impudent fool mean"? Sheikh Ali Yonsaef's organ remarks

"AL Lewa" has published an article on some high personages and therein it is insinuated that "The Great Emir" is one of that class of persons, who sacrfice their dignity for their pleasure and are willing to put up with end less insults, which renders them contemptible in the eyes of their friends, the natives, and their foes, the Occupants"

"Al Moayad" believes that these insinua tions are directed against no less a person than the Khedive. Kamel is severly taken to task for his audacity, but the latter refuses to reply. After having quoted various sentences from "Al Lewa" wherein stress is laid on the enormous expenses, which the country has been put to by the Khedival family. "Al Moayard" remarks that many people are repeating phrases used by Kamel, which bear a striking similarity to the words attributed to Arabi Pasha in 1882

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Prince Youssef Bey has arrived in Cairo
Lady Valda Machell is expected to arrive at Port Said from Europe to-day

The latest news in regard to Sir Auckland Colvin is that he is still in a very precarious condition. He has not rallied since his recent relaspe, and is now lying dangerously ill at his country home in Suffolk

Ibrahim Pasha Naguib, Under Secretary of Sate to the Ministry of the Interior, will now leave Egypt on Nov. 6th as delagate of the Egyptian Government at the International Sanitary COngress which is to be held in Rome on November 18th
Mr. D.A. Cameon, H.B.M's Consul General at Port Said, is somewhat better, but still has to be kept to the house

Mr. D'Abaza, the Russian Vice-Consul at Alexandria, was recieved in audience by the Khedive at Ras-el-Tin Palace on Monday and introduced Mr. Zouen, the newly appointed Russian Vice-Consul at Alexandria, to his Highness
Mr. J.E. Roberts, cheif engineer of the dockyard, returned from leave of absence on Monday by the N.D.L. S.S. "Sachsen"
Dr. and Mrs. Wakeling are returning to Egypt by the P. and O. S.S. "Caledonia" and are due at Mena House on the 31st inst.

Lord Cromer's cousin, Lord Ashburton, has sold his famous art collection to a group of well-known Bond-street dealers. This, one of the finest collections in England, was formed by Alexander Baring, the first Baron Ashburton of the new creation. He was an enthusiastic lover of the fine arts, and his wealth enabled him to fully gratify his taste, his Finnish and Dutch paintings especailly being of high qual ity. Most members of the Baring family have been collector of works of art; for instance, the Northbrook collection, part of which was sold some years bck, is of rare excellance.

div.head: ALEXANDERIA SWIMMING CLUB
div.p: On Saturday ladt at Gabbary, beofre a large number of spectators, the 60 yards juniors' and 110 yeards seniors' championships of the Club were decided. The juniors were represnted by the following :-- A.E.R. Ecclestone, age 6 last birthday, R.F. Ecclestone, age 10 last birthday, W. Keill, age 15 last birthday, H. Taylor, age 14 last birthday, D. A. Hamilton, age 15 last birthday, J.H. Mitchinson, age 15 last birthday.

Michinson led from the start followed close ly by Hamilton; the former however gradually increased his lead and won a good race by about 7ft. Keill, who was only taught to swim during the latter part of this season, was 3rd, some 3yds behind Hamilton

For the seniors rcae the following lined up:-- A.A Ecclestone, F.E. Howard, E. A. darton, C.E.L. Randall, P. Psycha, C.H. Lloyd, and A. Metzger. This proved a most exciting and interesting struggle; the bath was lengthen ed so that the competitors had to swim 3 lengths. The first four named were level at the 1st length, but Howard drew away and led by about a foot from Randall with Eccle stone and Dartona yard behind. The turn of the 2nd length found Howard a yard in fornt, but Randall (raied from the junior section last season) putting on a grand spurt drew level about 25 yards from home and eventually won by a yard and a half from Howard. There was a great struggle for thrid palce Darton (last year's winner) just beating Ecclestone by a touch, 2 yards behind Ho ward. It has been suffering somewhat from bronchitis lately, and was therefore not in his best form. After some capital dives by the juniors the club team met a team of the King's Royal Rifles in a 360 yards team race (each man swimming 60 yards) and won rather easily by about half a length. Also a polo match took place between the K.R.R and the club team. The K.R.R led at half time by one to nil, scored by Newton. At the re-start two of the Club team retired, their places being taken by Inglott and Martin, and the latter proving too hot for the opposing team contributed 4 goals in quick succession, the other goals being scored by Ecclestone (3) and Howard (2) to 1 by Newton for K.R.R
Result A.S.C 8 K.R.R 2
Thus a pleasant afternoon's swim was brought to a close

div.head: WINSTON CHURCHILIS VISIT.
div.p: Nicosia,October 18

The sayings and doings of Mr. Winston Churchill have been the all-engrossing topic of ingerest here during the past week. 1t would seem as if every possible section of the eom- munity, representing every phase of activity and shade of politics had been presented to him. He appears, moreover, to have received the numerous deputations with unvarying courtesy and, while paying careful attention to the manifold addresses and speselies deliver- ed; tohave nde it 'quite clear by his replies what the views of the British Government are, or what-line of action he was disposed to re- commend. His utterances were reasonably definite and ontapoken, and seem for that: very reason, rather more, perhaps, than for the matter expressed,'to have left a good impres- sion. The hope 1s generally entertained that as a result of his visita cleser personal interest in Oypras affairs will now manifest itself at the Colonial office in its dealings with this de pendecy

Mr. Churchill spent Friday last at Kyrenia, and was able to find time to visit from there the beantiful rained monastery of Bella Pais He also drove through the Nicosia bazaar ; inspected the central prison, saw the artesian wall boring machinery at work, and paid a visit |to'the white monastery of Kykko on the the outekirts of the town. He wasalso afford- ed opportunities of bevoming personally acquainted with a few English officials.

On Sunday morning (13th) he drove to Larnaca, where he was met by the Acting Commiasioner and the local authorities. After discharging various functions he rejoined H.M.S. "Venus," which had steamed over from Famagusta to be in readiness for him. He then proceeded to Limassol.
Some of the officers of H.M.S. "Venus" came up last week for a few days' stay at Nicosia

div.head: Need of English Newspaper.
div.p: On such oceasions as this one fells the. need of an English local newspaper. The ordinary English resident or visitor is only able to glean information of what is happening in the Island either from hearssy, which is mostly unre- liable, or by wading painfully through the verbose col of the native press. Sach a newspaper, the "Cyprus Herald," was started and carried on for a time in the early eighties, but for want of support, it was 'ere long aban doned and its place has never been filled

div.head: Museum Building Commenced
div.p: The Museum Committee has at length made a start on the building of the Museum This committee exists for the purpose of administering the funds raised during the Jubilee year with the object of erecting a museum, wherein Cypriot objects of antiquity and archeological remains may find a suitable resting place, and at the same time be open to public inspection. A central site has been selected for the building, on land given by Government, the plans have been approved and the foundations are now being begun. It is intended that the building now commenced shall be of modest dimensions, but so planned as to be capable of extension later as circum stances may require and funds permit.

div.head: PRAISE FROM CHICAGO
div.p: Mr. Bertrand Shadwell, of Chicago, has devoted part of his time to thinking about English people, and a poem ia the result of this pleasant oceupation. He composed three stanzas eight years ago; he has since been prompted to add another. The result of his contemplations may be gathered from the title of his verses. "There's Something in the Eng. lish after all." The last lines ot his kindly meant effort are—

Though the half of Europe hates them, and would joy in their decline, Yet there's something in the English after all: They may scorn the scanty numbers of the thin red Bri tish line, Yet they fear its lean battalions after all: For they know that from the colonel to the drum mer in the band There is not a single soldier in them all But would goto blind destruction, were their country to recommended And call it simply duty after all

div.head: CASINOS PAST AND PRESENT
div.p: From Our Own Correspondent
Mex, Monday.

At the sea's edge, between the villages of Mex and Dekhelah, nearer Dexbelah than Mex, is a deserted building bearing on the North side the legend "Casino et Hotel, Phase de Mex." It is of two stories with a wide balgony rupnipg round the spper storey and spacious verandahs Bast and West on the ground figor. On the;terraca, which projects into the sea, is a band.stand.and in the sea, bathing place bewn out of the natural rock. There. are out-buildings and a nicely shaded strip of garden at the back of the hetel. The whole however is rapidly becoming delapiteted. Oo the door of one of the out-buildings, over which is painted "Bnffet," are nailed two horse- shoes but the "luck" bas evidently departed. The casino, at one time, mast have been a delightful place to reoruit at and before the Government required the property, I am told some eight trains ren out from Alexandria to the casino on Sandays. To-day it has some- thing of the pathos of all deserted places and reminds us of Swinburn's "Forsaken Garden."

Some weeks ago, whilst waiting near the Ramleh station for a Mex tram, I observed a lady on the opposite canseway also waiting for someone or something, We eventually travelled on this same tram. She was young, good-look ing and well-dressed —in aword "chic." She was wearing a white skirt and blouse, small and dajnty white doe-skin shoes and a black straw hat trimmed with pose-coloured chiffon (I think it is termed) also a chatelaine from which depended several curious silver ornaments or weapons of the toilette. When the tram was slowly threading the slums of Gabbari I became curioas as to her destination. After consulting her watch with a feverish impatience at least a dozen times during the jonrney she left the tram at the new casino near the terminus. could not help speculating as to whom she was going to meet I might have grafitied my curiosity had I chosen to do so but it was, after all, no business of mine, and I trust they enjoyed the sunset which was particularly fine that evening. At this more modern casino, besides the attraction of sea-bathing, an excel lent meal may be obtained at a moderate figure and the proprietor stocks good cigars and claret. There are also I believe, band perform ances and balloon ascents periodically, but these I have neither heard nor seen

div.head: The Salt Lake.
div.p: After leaving the old Casino yesterday I wended my way between several Bedouin tents to the brow of the quarry opposite, which, with its lime-kilns and blasting operations, is a hive of industry. To the left, under the lee of the cliff, some of the Army of Occupation are encamped in their usual summer quacters, than which none could be healthier. In front stretches the great Salt Lake from which the concessionaires have recently, in a few weeks, extracted over 50,000 tons of salt. The lake appears to be about 1 3/4 miles across at this point and extends some 19 miles in a S.W. direction. The surface bears the appearance of a sheet of ice on which snow has partially melted and frozen again. To those in search of novelty I would suggest,

div.head: A Moter Trip
div.p: round the lake. The surface would readily permit of a motor bring driven over any portion and permission could doubtless be obtained trom the concessionaires. I could imagine nothing more delightful than a spin over the lake in the moonlight, there being no obstacles to bar the way. Writing of moter cars and obstacles reminds me of the clas sifieation (attributed to Mr. A. J. Balfour) of those who habitually obstruct the passage of motor cara, as "Ihe Quick and the Dead.'

div.head: Arctic exploration in Egypt
div.p: For the encouragement of tourists in search of a warm winter climate | suggest that a series of photographs be taken of the lake and inserted in such periodicals as the "By stander" and the "Sketch." A few individuals enveloped in fur coats would lend added realism to the scene. When, a few evenings since, the sunset cast a ruddy glow over the lake the scene was positively arctic.

div.head: Bird Lite at Mex.
div.p: The quail season is now practically over and the chain of nets round the coast hays been removed. From my window, I have ob- served every morning for sometime past lange flights of duck coming in from the sea, alan flocks or heron probably making for the feed ing grounds in Upper Egypt now that the Nile is subsiding. I have also seen two red breasts, a desertchat, a rose-linnet or red-pol! and a very fine kingfisher of the large variety. This last I saw on the rocks whilst I was swimmingand by moving cautiously throagh the water which wascovered with floating sea wead, I got within fonr yards of the bird which was a magnificent plamaged specimen. Po botanists the flora in the neighbourhood of Mex would, I imagine, prove very interesting bat I am not sufficiently acquainted with the subject to write abont it.

div.head: CAIRO PICTURES.
div.p: BEYOND THE CITY GATES.
By Artuur Delany

The bustle of the town becomes appalling at times; the gilt nauseous; then in a modern train—with primitive instincts, we leayg the "idly busy" world of Cairo, and allow the green fields to envelope us with no parting regret.

Peeping above the trees, the sails of Arab dhows apon the Nile are seen, and through fields of maize and cotton we pursue our way. The minarets of the numerous mosques gradu ally disappear from view, except the two, lofty and elegant, that guard the mosque of Mehe- met Ali, and are still to be seen against the old Mokattams long after the other works of man have been hidden by nature.

The length of the journey is sufficient to permit ns to moralise upon the city left behind, and what is the mental picture? We find that, as with other great cities, where life holds a strange incongraous mixture, from which men of all tastes can be satisfied in the observance of men and their ways, so it is with Cairo, but there is, however, in Egypt's capital the addi- tion of many races to supplement the study of humanity.

We may see the ostentatious finery of some gilded youth, and the loose flowing galabieh that partly hides, the slouch of the native There, is the pantomime of life. The leer of the sensnalist ; the unstained beauty of the child. The hard look of the money-grubber ; the contented face of the man, who, by his gabardine, tells us the follies of this earth have been renounced. All are there! Pursuing their different courses tending either to good, or evil

"East is East, and West is West, and never the twain shall meet"- bat they nearly do in Cairo. The Occident, however, is winning a victory. and the Orient must succamb. For the moment the blend is adulterated. As grandeur rashes by resplendant in the modera lanary of the latest automobile, a native omnibus pursues the even tenor of its way drawn by animals fast approaching the stage, if they have not already reached it, which terminates in beef-essence. Nowhere is the sublime so neatly allied to the ridiculous, as in Cairo.

But we mast stop moralising, and leave the city behind, for Matarieh bas been reached — "the place belonging to the sun." Near by is old Heliopolis, that was before Abraham, and the eternalpyramids,—"the city of thé sun"— and thus Matarieh derived its name.

Evading the donkey boys, which requires as much skill as would bring an army to victory, we break from the human tracks. The extent of force which environment has upon character is amply felt here. Where everything speaks of peace we feel perforce that we must be at peace with the world. There is no sonnd save that made by the birds, who apparently are no less happy than ourselves. Through an avenue of sycamore, orange, palm, and banana trees we pass into the open, where further progress is stayed by the approach of an old friend. He is the loeal guide, and on our original visit told more untruths regarding the traditions of Matarieh, than we have since learned of the actual truth We always havea chat, because philosophy bubbles over in bim. Kant, Sehel- ling, or Bacon, would perhaps, have blushed at Arab philosophy, but to us it is as "caviare to the General." Our friend's left eye showed unmistakeable signs of having been tampered with ; in fect ; it was in a state of disrepair. It exhausted a lot of persuasive power to learn that he had lost the day (and, incidently, nearly his,eye) in a quarrel, but the inherent philosophy ot his kind did not forsake him, and readily wonld the subject have been disinis- sed by the Arabic word, which is equivalent to "never mind" in our language, had we not suggested that the damaged eye looked as if it would be closed for along time. This afforded him an opportunity, and with an almost im perceptible wink in the other, he remarked "Yea, but it will reopen again for the tourist season."

Speaking of Arabian philosophy calls to mind that ofan Arab chieftain, one of the most powerfal of the prinoes of the desert, who, for the first time, beheld a steamship. Much at tention was paid to him, and every facility affomded for sis inspestion of every part of the vessel What- impression the sight made upon him it was impossible to judge ; no indications of surprise escaped him; every muscle pre served its wonted calmnéss of expression ; and on quitting he merely observed. "It is well bat you have not brought a man to life yet."
Let us retarn from this digression Matarieh is an absorbing place to those who permit tradition to pass unquestioned, but
"Who shall decide, when dootors disagree" "And soundest casuists duubt, like you, and me"

The tale of our friend, the guide, to en thusiastic Americans, who gaze at the historic tree which is supposed to have sheltered the Virgin and Child aftet their flight into Egypt, now protected by railings from the Yankee penknife, differs considerably from the in formation to be obtained from the Synaxaires of the Copts, — very old works. And there.is a divergence of opinion among writers, old and modern, as to thetrath ofthe current traditions, and whether Old Cairo, as it is now called, or Matarieh, had the honour of harbouring the Virgin and Child during the two years they lived in Egypt.

Formerly, the garden, in which one may be- hold interesting biblical monoments, was known aa the "Jardin de Baume." but the balm has !ong sinee disappeared. The opinion of the time was, that the plant would not grow without the aid of water from the neigh- boaring well, supposed to be miraculous as being the bathing: place of the infant Child.

Whatever there may beinthe trailitions of Matarieh, the fact remains they are strengthen- ed by constant reference through the course of successive centuries ; so we must not be too sceptical, but leave "the place belonging to the san" in full enjoyment of its history, and its local guide, who, perhaps after all, is the most interesting monument there.

The "stealthy motion of time" bids us re- turn to the town. We still can see on the return journey, against the back-ground of evening red, the dhows upon the Nile. The green fields look more beautiful still, bat we know in a few moments all will be swallowed up in darkness, and once more we will be among the artificial joys of the town.

div.head: EGYPTIAN STATE RAILWAYS.
div.p: WINTER TRAIN SERVICE
CAIRO—ALEXANDRIA
The following changes have been introduced in the train service coming into force on November 1st.
1. The 4.50 p.m. express from Cairo and the 4.25 p.m. express from Alexandria will resume running as last year and will convey Ist and 2nd class passengers, stopping at Tantab and Sidi Gaber only,
2. The 7.10am. and 5.85 p.m. expresses from Cairo and Tantah respectively will be suppressed.
3. The 12 noon luncheon car expresses from Cairo and Alexandria will arrive at Alexandria and Cairo at 8.5 p.m. respectively.
4. The 5.50 am, local train from Cairo to Tantah has been retimed to leave at 6 a.m.
5. The 8.20a.m. train from Cairo to Alexandria will arrive at 225 p.m. and the 5.45 am. train from Tantah to Alexandria will leave at 5 50 and arrive at 9.15a.m.
6. To meet the demands of the public a new express train has been put on between Alex andria, Tantah and back.

It will leave Alexandria at 1030 am., connecting at Damanhour with the train leav- ing at 12 noon for Dessouk and return from Tantah at 2.15 pm. with the passengers from the branches who may be foand at Tantah and will connect at The El-Baroud with the train leaving for Manachi Line at 5.20 a.m.

7. The 4pm _ express train from Cairo to Alexandria will stop at Teh-el-Barond to take the passengers of the Teh-El-Baroud line arriv- ing at 4.55 p.m. conseqnently the 6.35 p.m train will not stop there and will arrive Alex andria 5 minutes earlier. The former train will therefore reach Alexandria 5 minutes later.
8. The 10am. train from Alexandria to Cairo will leave at 910 am. as apicking up train ahead of the new express from Alexandria.

9. The 2.10 p.m. train from Alexandria has been retimed to lewe Tantah at 6.20 p.m and arrive Cairo at 8.35 p.m. instead of 8.15 and therefore the 8 p.m. train from Cairo has been retimed to leave Tantah at 6. 8 p.m and arrive Alexandria at 9.30 instead of 8.55 p.m
10. The 3.45 p.m. train from Alexandria will leave at 3.40.
Mau Line Catro, Zacazia anv Port Saw.
1. The present mixed train leaving [smatha at 8am for Port Said will arrive at 10.55 am instead of 11.35 and the one from Port Baid to Ismailia will leave at 2 p.m. instead of 1 p.m.

2. A new local train has been organised be- tween Zagazig, Benha and back. It will leave Zagazig at 5.45 a.m. reaching Benha at 6.40 a.m. and connect with the train leaving Berha for Cairo at 7.3 a.m. and those leaving for Tantah and Alexandria at 716 and 8.15 am This train returns from Benba at 7.40 p.m after receiving the passengers from Cairo and Alexandria arriving at Benha by the 6.35 p.m., 2.10 and 3.40 p.m. trains respectively

1. The mixed trains leaving Calioub and Zagesig at am. and 3.50 pm. respectively will be suppressed

2. A new local train has been organised be- tween Casiro-Zagazig and back. It starts from Cairo at 5.45 am. and arrives at Zagarig at 7.55 am. thus connecting with the trains leaving for Minet el-Gamh and Benha at 8 21 am. This train returns from Zagasig at 7.45 pm. after taking the passengers arriving there at 3 p.m

8. The 6. and 930 am. trains from Man- sourah will arrive at Cairo at 10.50 am. and 1,55 p.m. respectively insted of 10.45 and 1.50 p.m. and the 4.15 p.m, train from Man sourah will reach Cairo 10 minutes earlier.
4. The 11.30 a.m. and 5.25 p-m. trains from Cairo for Mansonrah will leave at 11.25 am. and 5.40 p.m. respectively and follow the present timing from Zagazig to Mansourah.
5. The 9.30a.m train from Mansourah will leave Zagazig 5 minutes later ie.at 11.50 am. instead of 11.45 after receiving the passengers of the Port-Said Line arriving there at 11.41 a.m

1. To meet the requirements of the public who need to settle their affairs early at the Tribunal and to enable the Post Office to have the mail arriving from Cairo and Alexandria by the night trains, distributed early in the morning the 6.45 a.m. train from Tanteh has been retimed to leave at 5 30a.m. and to arrive at Damiette at 9.15.

2. The 7. a.m., 2 p.m. and 4 p.m. trains from Damiette will start in future at 7.10 a.m., 2.5 p.m and 4.10 p.m. respectively arriving at Tantah at the present timings and the 6.15 p.m. train from Tantah will arrive at Damiette at 9.85 instead of at 9.45 p.m
Zifteh Line

1. On the Zifteh Line the train now leaving Tantah at 5.40 am. will leave ot 5.15 a.m. and the train leaving Zifteh at 8.0.m. will leave at 6.55 a.m. to connect at Mehallet 'Roh witli the train leaving for Tantah at 8.16 am, This arrangement will enable the passengers on the Zifteh Line to proceed to Cairo or Alexandria by the morning expresses.
2. The train now leaving Zifteh at 8.10 p.m. will leave at 8. and reach Tantali at 9.80 p.m. instead of 10.5 p.m.

1. On the Dessouk Line the train now leav- ing Tantah at 5am. will reach Damanhour 5 minutes earlier.
2. On the Cherbine Line, the trein now leaving Biala at 7 am. will leave at 6.40 a.m to connect at Cherbine with the train leaving Tantab at 5.30 a.m.

The train leaving Menouf at 11.85 am. will leave at 11.40 and reach 'T'antah 5 minutes garlierand the train leaving Tantah at 6.25 p.m. will leave 5 minates later.

On the Barrage Line the present trains leav- ing Cairo at 6.10 am., 8.45 p.m. and 5.40 p.m. will leave at 6.15a.m., 940 and 5.25 p.m. res- pectively and the trains leaving Barrage at 2.55 and 655 p.m. will leave at 2.50 and 6.20 p.m
Mit Berah Line.

1. On the Mit Berah Line a new train has been organised to leave Mit Berah at 6.15 am. and arrive at Benba-at 6.85 connecting with the train leaving for Cairo at 7.3 atm. and with-those-leaving-for-Tantah and "Alex: andria at 7.16 and 8.15 am. This train will return from Benba at 5 pm. after taking the passengers arriving from Cairo by the trains leaving at 3and 4 p.m. and from Tantah by the train leaving at 2.80 p.m.

2. The trains leaving Mit Berah at 3.30 and 8.50 p.m. will leave at 2.40 and 5.40 p.m. respectively and the train leaving Benha at 725 p.m. will leave at 8.50 p.m. after receiving the passengers arriving from Cairo by the train leaving at 6.35 and 7.15 p.m. and from Alexandria by the 6 p.m. train.
Upper Egypt Lines

1. On the Cairo-Luxor Line the express leaving Cairo at 8.80 am will run as an express between Sohag-Luxor and will only stop at certain stations shown in the Time Table Sheet, arriving Luxor at 11.35 p.m.

2. A new train has been armngail.to leave Sohag at 3 p.m. for Luxor mat 815 p.m. will pick up at all stations train will enable the passengers. for Guergueh, Baliana, Nag-Hamadi, Keneh and Laxor to arrive early.

8. The train leaving Luxor at 6.10 a.m. for Cairo has been made an express between Luxor-Sohag and will leave at 7 am. stopping at certain stations shewn in the Time Table Sheet, consequently a local train has, been arranged to leave Luxor at 5.45 am. for Sohag ahead of the above train.
4. The train now leaving Cairo at 9.30 a.m. for Assiout has been made to arrive Assiowt 40 minutes earlier and the one leaving at 5.15 p-m. for Minieh will arrive 20 minutes earlier.
The night express leaving Cairo for Luxor at 8. p.m willarrive 20 minutes earlier and that leaving at 9.30 p.m. for Assiont will atrive 15 minutes earlier.
The train now leaving Assiout at 5.80 am. for Luxor will leave at 5.20 arriving at 1.20 p.m.

5. The Lux trains which used to ran during the tourist season will resume running from the 2nd of December three times per week leaving Cairo at 6.30 p.m. and from Luxor at 6.30 p.m. commencing from the 8rd. The public will be notified when this train is to be ran daily. A 2nd class coach will be attached to these trains for the servants of Ist class pas sengers only.
6. The morning express train now leaving Minieh at 6.5 a.m. for Cairo will leave at 6.20 and arrive 5 minutes earlier.
The local train now leaving Wasta at 6.40 a.m. for Sohag will arrive 5 minutes later and the one leaving Sohag at 9.15 a.m. for Wasta will also artive 5 minutes later.

1. The night eapress leaving Laxor at 5.30 p.m. for Cairo will arrive at 7.5 instead of 7.::0 a.m. and the train now leaving Assiout at 10.40 p.m. for Cairo will leave at 10.50 and arrive 1 5minutes earlier.
Fayoum and Sennoures Line.

1: On the Fayoum Line, the train now leav- ing Fayoum at 5.80 a.m. for Cairo will leave at 5.40 and arrive at 9.35 instead of at 9. am owing to the organization of the Luxe train whieh will ran ahead of this train at Wasta and the-train mow 'leaving Cairo at 6.40 p.m. for Fayoum will leave 5 minutes later and arrive 15 minutes earlier.

2. A new train will be run between Wasta, Payoum and Abouxah and back. This train starts from Wasta at 6.55 a.m with the pas- sengers of the Upper Egypt Line 'Arriving at Wasta by the night expresses for Fayoum Line. This train returns from Abooxah at 10a.m. for Wasta with the passengers desiring to leave for-Upper Egypt by the train leaving Wasta at 12.9 p.m.
8. The train now leaving Abouxah at 6.40 a.m. for Payoum and Wasta will leave 10 minutes earlier.

4. On the Sennoures line a new train will leave Fayoum at 8.30 a.m. for Sennoores with the passengers arriving from Upper Egypt by the new train. This train returns from Sennoures at 9.30 am. connecting at Fayoom with the new train from Abouxah.
The train now leaving Fayoum at 10.50 p.m. for Sennoures will leave 15 mts. earlier.
Assouan Line.

On this line two new trains will be run between Assouan and Shellal and back from Ist of Desetiber but may be suppressed at any time aftét the public has been advised. These tynins start from Assouan at 9 am. and 4 p.m and from Shellal at 10.5 a.m. and 2.50 p.m

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui à midì)

Toute l'attention de notre marché a été con centreé, comme hier, sur le Comptoir Finan cier et Commercial (Campos). On évalue à environ un millier le nombre de titres qui ont changv de mains. C'est le Caire quivend, ainsi que le démonstre l'activité des arbitra gistes, et sur norte place c'est principalement la petite spéculation qui achéte, sur le bruit que la prochaine assemblée de la société en tendrait un rapport des plus satisfaisants. Grâce à l'absorption rapide des petits paquets mis en vente, le prix a progressé de 2 29/32 à 3 1/8 l'ancienne action, de 2 31/32 à 3 3/16 la nouvelle et de 2 à 2 1 8 la part de fonda teur. Il a été vendu aux enchéres publiques 25 actions anciennes au prix de 3 1/32.

Des transaction ont été également effec tuées, mais en quantité et nombre insigni fiants, sur la National Bank. Ces derniers, étant offerts, ont fléchi de 9/16 à 1/2. La National Bank béneficie de 1/16 à 21 13/16; l'Agricole reste stationaire à 8 1/4; et la Delta Land est un peu plus faible à 1 7/16.

Toujours sur la rumeur d'un bon coupon, l'Ordinary Khedivial Mail a été recherchve durant toute la matinée, mais sans veudeurs. Le cours a monté de ce chef de 22/6 à 23/3. Vers la fin les Nungovich Hotels ont été l'ob jet d'une poussée de 16 3/4 à 17 3/8, sans qu'il y ait-eu d'échanges. Au contraire, de offres ont ramené encore la Béhéra de 23 1/4 à 23.

C'est & peu prés tout ce que la séance de ce matin a offert de saillant. Comme on le voit, les affaires, excepts en Comptoir, ont été pres- que nulles. Aussi led fluctuations de la cote n'ont-elles pas eu d'envergure

A part celles déjà signaleées, les Privilégiées Tramways rétrogradent de 141 à 140, les Jouissance Eaux du Caire de 192 à 190, la Daïra de 13 5/8 à 13 1/2, les Markets de 26/- 25/6, la Salt & Soda de 18/- 4 17/9, Aboukir de 28/6 & 28/-, et la fondateur Allotment de 60 & 58 P.T., tandis que l'Obligation nouvelle Crédit Foncier avance de 253 à 253 1/2, et l'Union Foncitte de 4 8/4 & 4 13/16.

Sur le reste de la cote, il n'y a pas de change- ment à signaler. La tendapce est indécise, car on ne peat considérer l'activité circonscrite an Comptior comme l'indice d'une amélioration générale. L'ensemble de la spéculation reste sur ses positions, dan l'attente d'une direction venant des places dirigeantes, ou malheureuse ment la baisse des valeurs américanes exerce la plus pernicieuse influence. De plus, le taux privé d'escompte vient d'étre élevé en Angle terre à 4 1/2%. Bien que ec soit là un événe ment préyu pour la saison, il a néanmoins un certain effet déprimant, lorqu'il est accom pagné d'autres circonstances.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES BT CRITIQUES
Le Caire, Mardi 22 Octobre.
Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres est renseigné invarié à 4 1/2 pour cent.

Au Stock-Exchange, le Consolidé anglais a haussé hier de 1/8 à 88 3/8. L'Unifiée a été ferme à 102 3/4. La National Bank et l'Agricole ont été soutenues à 22 et 8 3/8 respectivement. La Daira s'est maintenue à 13 3/4 et la Delta Light à 10 3/8.
A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Egyptien a gagné 4 france & 692. La Banque d'Athénes a perdu 1 franc & 110. Les Lots Turcs se sont conso- lidés & 168.

Ici, ainsi nots le faisions remarquer heir, le marché parait s'orienter vers une légtre repreise, et la néance d'aujourd'hui peut étre taxée sans exagération de séance de consolida tion. En effet, l'ouverture a été relativement animée at si peu aprés le salme s'est rétabli, la cloture a enregistré néanmoins un raffermisse ment sur nombre de valuers. Les transactions ont égalament montré un léger progrés, ce qui donne à penser que les liquidaations intempes tives de ces derniers jours s'arrétant le marché pourreit facilement prendre une allure haus siére. Cels n'aurait, du reste, rien d'excessif pour certains titres, vu l'état prospére de leur affaires

Dans le compartiement de Banques, la Na tional Bank garde non cours d'heir à 21 11/16- 3/4. L'Agricole est réalisée à 8 1/4. La Banque d'Orientse tasse à 118-119. La Cassa diSconto reprend 2 francs à 50-51. Le Comptoir Finan cier et Commercial se reléve à 2 15/16-3. Les H. de Vries and Boutigny Ltd./ ont un fort courant de transactions qui les fait cloturer trés demandées à un cours légérement supérieur à celui d'hier.

La Daira Sanieh recule à 13 1/2-9/16. Le Crédit Foncier Egyptien se raffermit à 690, son obligation ancienne es demandée à 297-298 tandis que la nouvelle est plutot offerte à 253. La Béhéra rétrograde à 23 1/4 et son obliga tion à 4 3/8. L'Enterprise and Development est ramenée à 8 1/2. Les fondateurs Entresprises et Travaux remontent à P. T. 39. Les Hélio polis sont négligées à 235 et leur part à 10 13/16.
Dans le groupe des Hotels, les Nungovich sont en léger gain à 16 5/8 et les Egyptian Hotels(Bachler) de meme à 6 1/16-1/8. Les Ritz sont plus faibles à 0 1/2-9/16/

Parmi les petites valeurs, la Delta Land est encore plus lorse à 1 7/16. L New Egyptian reperd son avance d'hier à 13/-. Les Walker and Meimarachi sont un peu unieux à 0 5/16- 3/8. Les Hecher sont peu soutenus à 0 1/4-5/16 que les Glierireh Mausions sont en avance à 0 1/4-5/8.

A propos de récentes difficultés du marché américan qui, comme on sait, ont provoqué une rafulé de baisce en Europe, et par contre coup sur le merché égyptien, il faudrait, assure t-on s'attendré à une amélioration graduelle, témoin les déclarations suivautes d'un financier américain:

"Samedi, le bo bilan de Banques associées n'a guére mordu sur le pessimisme renforcé de la place, il y a su des instanta de panique menacante. On dissait la-bas que le Groupe Harriman allait congédier 20,000 employés de ses lignes et se voyait forcé d'adopter d'austres grandes économies. On trouve étonnant que la Haute Banque n'ait pas mieux cherché a sou tenir la cote, et un éminent critique financier estime que la situation peut devenir bien grave, si l'on n'organise pas immédiatement au soutien énergique; il ajoute que les conditions présentes se prétent a de sérieux troubles, ce qui n'échappe pas d'ailleurs aux personnages a la téte de ce mouvement

"Toutefois, tons les juges ne sont pas d'sc- cord ; il y a une mindrité estimant que !'ex- tréme faiblesse récente n'a pas de nouvelle cause physique A sa base, mais est die pure- ment A un état mental démoralisé par les derniéres épreuves ; un grand banquier d'outre- mer déolaré que la disparition graduelle des engagements spéculatifs en valeurs de Bourse, ainsi que Yindubitable déclin modéré de l'in- prodaire ane sensible détente du loyer de Vargent ; il prédit que déja en décembre pro- ichain, il y aura grande abondance monétaire, Jide sorte que l'Amérique pourra nous envoyer de l'or, au lieu de nous en demander.
"Voila pourquoi on ne peut pas approuver entiérement les prédictions si noires de l'heure présente".
Carnet de l'actionnaire.

MM. les actionngires de la "Société H. de Vries and Boutigny Ltd," sont avisés que le solde du sur leurs actions est payable au plus tard le 24 Octobre courant plus les intéréts de retard caloulés au taux de 9 % l'an.
Faute par eux deffectuer ledit paiement dans le délai fixé, il lear sera fait application des art 20 et 21 des Statuts dont la teneur est la suivante:

Art. 20. If any Member fail to pay any call or instalment on or before the day appointed for the payment of the same, the Directors may at any time thereafter, during such time as the call or instalment remains unpaid, serve a notice on such Member requiring him to pay the same, together with any interests that have accrued and all expenses that may have been incurred by the Company by reason of such non-payment.

Art. 21, The notice shall name a day (not being less than fourteen days from the date of the notice) and place or places on and at which such call or instalment and such interest and expenses'as aforesaid are to be paid. The notice shall also state that in the event of non- payment at or before the time and at the place appointed, the shares in respect of which the call was made or instalment is payable will be liable to be forfeited

— MM. les actionnaires de la "Walker and Meimarechi Ltd," qui avaient déposé leurs actions & |'Anglo-Egyptian Bank, aux fins d'étre réprésentés A l'assemblée du 17 écoalé, sont priés de les laisser jusqa'é nouvel avis, la convocation d'une nouvelle assembi¢e devant probablement avoir lieu pour obliger le Conseil d' Administration de Londres 4 se conformer aux décisions prises.

div.head: Angio-Egyptian Finance and Exchange Company ltd
div.p: AVIS

Il est porté & la connaissance de MM. les Actionnaires que le Conseil d' Administration a décidé de proroger jasqa'au 5 Mai 1908, l'époque de la déchéance prinitivement fixée pour le 5 Novembre 1907, a l'encontre des actions sur lesquelles les versements appelés a la date du 20 Septembre 1907 n'avaient pas été effectués, les actionnaires retardataires restant passibles du paiement des intéréts & raison de 9 % l'an & partir des dates respec- tives de versements non effectués 31150-3*-1

div.head: AVIS
div.p: La Municipalité met en adjudication les travaux de prolongement de la rue des Parcs au sud de l'ancien cimetière israélite jusqu'au fort el Nahas.
Le cautionnement est fixé à LE. 15.
Le cahier des charges est déposé an Bureau de la Voirie où il peut-être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. à midi, les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 18 courant.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation la même jour à 5h.p.m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention: "Soumission pour les travaux de prolongement de la rue des Parcs."

Le cautionnement ou le reçu d'une banque, d'après les conditions du cahier des charges, devra être remis séparément au Service de la Comptabilité Générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 18 courant à midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera écartée.
L'Administrateur.
(signé) W.P. Chataway.
Alexandrie, le 7 juillet 1905.

div.head: Supplement Commercial et Financier.
div.p: De "L'Egyptian Gazette"

Le Supplément Commercial et Financier de l' "Egyptian Gazette" paraît chaque Samed à midi, de façon à pouvoir être expédié par le paquebot autrichien. Il contient des revues complètes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marché des valeurs; les dernières statistiques jusqu'à la veille de sa publication: des tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies des dépêches officielles envoyées à la Liverpool Cotton Association, etc etc
L'abonnement pour une année en Egypte coûte 1 L.E. y compris les frais de poste; pour l'étranger 10 P.T. de port en sus.

div.head: A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.
div.p: This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. Now, what alone is absolutely essential in all such cases is increased vitality—vigour--
VITAL STRENGTH & ENERGY
to throw off these morbid feelings, and experience proves that as night succeeds the day this may be more certainly secured by a course of the celebrated life-reviving tonic
THERAPION No.3
than by any other known combination. So surely as it is taken in accordance with the printed directions accompanying it, will the shattered health be restored,
THE EXPIRING LAMP OF LIFE LIGHTED UP AFRESH,

and a new existence imparted in place of what had so lately seemed worn-out, "used up," and valueless. This wonderful medicament is purely vegetable and innocuous, is agreeable to the taste —suitable for all constitutions and conditions, in either sex; and it is difficult to imagine a case of disease or derangement, whose main features are those of debility, that will not be speedily and permanently benefited by this never-failing recuperative essence, which is destined to cast into oblivion everything that had preceded it for this wide-spread and numerous class of human ailments.
